title: Debt collectors doing little to repair image
text:
The debt collection industry is punching above its weight in terms of complaints with data from the Australian Collectors and Debt Buyers Association saying the sector has $20 billion under collection across 7.5 million accounts administered by 3190 employees.

By way of comparison the Australian superannuation sector manages $2.9 trillion in assets, across more than 22 million accounts and is administered by more than 100,000 employees.

AFCA says that credit cards, personal loans, non-financial firm product debt, lines of credit and overdrafts are the most commonly complained about products.

Many banks have ceased selling bad debts attached to some of these products to debt collection agencies because they do not like their methods of collection.

Pioneer scrutinised

A recommendation that debt collection firm Pioneer Credit breached the guidelines and should pay $1000 toward a $13,000 debt it was trying to recover for making excessive contact is typical of the misconduct seen in the sector.

AFCA declined to comment on the specifics of the case as the matter is current and under consideration.

The complainant brought the case to the regulator claiming Pioneer Credit had harassed him, his son and his neighbours about the debt while also threatening to leave a black mark on his credit file.

Advertisement

In a case of extreme irony, Pioneer Credit last month defaulted on its own debts and had its funding cut off by the banks after a stoush with its auditor saw the debt collector entering a trading halt from which it has yet to emerge.

AFCA found Pioneer Credit did make excessive contact and noted on one occasion the company attempted to contact the debtor on four separate occasions on one day in breach of the guidelines, with three of those attempts taking place before 6am.

“Unnecessary or unduly frequent contacts may amount to undue harassment. The debt collection guidelines recommend that contact with a debtor should not exceed three times per week, or 10 times per month at most,” the recommendation says.

The recommendation, however, does find largely in favour of Pioneer Credit.

The case analyst found that the $12,000 debt should stand, that contacting the debtor’s neighbours was appropriate in the circumstances and the threat to list a default was in keeping with the sector’s guidelines.

Pioneer Credit and the complainant have 30 days from September 30 to decide whether they accept or reject the recommendation.
description: The niche debt collection sector generates one in every 25 complaints submitted to the regulator.
